Thus the body ingests the divine elixir of flowering cinnabar, and no perverse qi can harm it, nor can illness befall it. To say that consuming the flowering cinnabar cures all ailments is to declare that no sickness will afflict one.

Fortunate is the one who attains transcendence—auspicious and without misfortune. "Auspicious and without misfortune" means the body endures for ten thousand generations, following the Perfected Ones. Fortunate is the one who transcends the world for ten thousand years and more. If you diligently study this, you too may attain immortality.

Explanation: The method for refining the flowering cinnabar elixir involves taking alum, halite, bittern, and arsenolite—four substances—and first firing them for twenty days. Then, take leftward-turning oysters from the Eastern Sea, red stone, talc, and seven other ingredients, adjusting their quantities as needed. Pound them ten thousand times until they become powder, then place them in an iron vessel and fire them for nine days and nine nights, intensifying the flame until the medicine glows red as fire. Pound it again ten thousand times, sift it through fresh silk, and blend it with well-fermented hundred-day wine to create the "Six-One Mud." Coat the inside and outside of two red clay crucibles with this mud, each layer three fen thick, and dry them in the sun for over ten days until thoroughly desiccated. Then, take lead powder and fire it until it turns golden. Next, take equal parts of dark yellow and yellow substances, mix them with hundred-day Hua Pond liquid to form a paste, pound them ten thousand times, and coat the inside of the two red clay crucibles with a three-fen-thick layer. Apply another three-fen-thick layer to the outside and dry them in the sun for ten days until completely dry.

Then, place two jin of cinnabar into the crucible, adjusting the quantity of medicine as needed—from one jin at the base to ten jin at the top, or even a hundred jin, with no fixed amount. The poor may prepare less, the wealthy more. A crucible large enough to hold eight or nine sheng can accommodate one and a half dou. Those from Rongyang, Henan, Luoyang, and Yingchuan command high prices, with each crucible costing fourteen or fifteen coins. First, coat the crucibles inside and out with Six-One Mud, each layer three fen thick, and dry them in the sun for ten days until thoroughly desiccated before use.

Place the cinnabar into the crucible and seal it, allowing it to dry for over ten days. Ensure the crucible’s mouth and seams are tightly sealed to prevent any leakage. Before the cinnabar ascends, first heat the crucible with horse dung fire, piling earth around the crucible’s edges with the fire five cun away. "Tongqing" refers to horse dung; if unavailable, use chaff fire. Heat it for nine days and nine nights, then push the fire closer for another nine days and nine nights, placing the crucible directly over the flame. For the next nine days and nine nights, mound the fire halfway up the crucible. After a total of thirty-six days of firing, it will be ready. Let it cool for a day, then open it—the cinnabar will have ascended and adhered to the upper crucible. Sweep it off with a rooster’s feather: it will appear purple-red, shimmering with five colors, sometimes like streaking stars or swirling red, other times like frost or snow, or pure red as cinnabar. One jin of this substance yields only four liang.

If the medicine resists the fire and does not rise, it is called "flowering cinnabar." Blend it with dragon fat, form pellets the size of small beans, and place them over a fierce fire. With bellows, blow on them for the time it takes to cook a meal, and they will turn into gold. If the medicine does not ascend and instead becomes powdered mercury, fire one jin of it with twenty-four zhu, and it too will become gold. Use this to fashion gold and silver plates to hold the medicine. To ingest it, take a pellet the size of a small bean, face the sun, bow twice, and consume it. If the medicine does not submit to the fire, refine it again. Mix it with dark water, dragon fat, and moisture until damp, then place it back into the dark yellow and red clay crucible, seal it properly, and fiercely fire it for another thirty-six days until the medicine is complete. In total, seventy-two days will suffice.

When preparing the medicine, begin on an auspicious day such as the first day of the sexagenary cycle, the day of the "Opening" or "Removal" in the almanac. Before compounding the medicine, fast and purify yourself for three days. No more than two or three people should participate, and they must be of one mind, for "two in harmony can cut through metal." Focus your intent and avoid entering defiled or impure households. When firing the medicine, perform a ritual offering at the crucible’s edge with clear wine, fragrant cakes, a dou of millet, three dou of jujubes, and a dou of pears. Arrange three tables, each with three cups, and as the incense rises, bow twice and pray:

"Lesser servant so-and-so, on this day, refines the Nine Elixirs. May the divine immortals, the Mysterious Woman, the Plain Woman, and the Green-Waisted Jade Maidens assist in its completion. May the Lord of the Great Dao, Lord Lao, and the Lord of Grand Harmony grant this lesser servant so-and-so the medicine of immortality and the wine of the divine immortals."

Rise, bow twice, and complete nine bows. Then recite:

"May the Lord of the Dao and the Mysterious Woman ensure the medicine does not flee, that it submits to the fire, and that its color is fine and good. May it transform at will, yielding both yellow and white. May those who consume it ascend to the Purple Palace, their lives boundless, their rank that of a Perfected One."

Then offer the wine. After the wine is presented, offer all manner of red fruits and citrus fruits. When preparing the divine medicine, do not allow fools, women, children, mourners, the impure, or those with sharp tongues and envious hearts to witness it. If they do not follow the Dao, do not let them know of it, lest the medicine fail to form. Take care that no guests or women linger near the medicine. Why? The medicine requires absolute silence to succeed. Fools who doubt the Dao and deny the existence of divine medicines must not see it, or the medicine will not form.

Carefully monitor the crucible to ensure no cracks, holes, or damage—even as small as a hair or an ant’s nose—lest the medicine escape, its spirit vanish, its soul dissipate, leaving only stone behind and squandering its precious essence. The medicine will then be ineffective and offer no benefit to those who consume it. One zhu of the divine medicine, when cast into a jin of mercury and fired, will turn it into gold. If it does not become gold, the medicine is unfit for consumption.

Thus the Mysterious Woman said: "If gold can be made, the world can be transcended. If gold cannot be made, one only harms oneself."

chunks.original_text: 即以丹一铢，粉铅锡水银各一斤，粉之皆成金银。 故言斤斤与一铢，慎无多也。 常以平旦日出时，束向再拜，长跪服之，如禾粟。 上士服之，七日得仙升九皇。 下士服之，七十日乃得仙。 愚人服之，一年乃得仙。 欲作神药，服药时皆先斋戒，沐浴五香，不如法，药不成也。 以丹华釜飞神符，大善。 子无贪财，但飞神药，可得神仙，勿得妄传。 真人日：第二之丹名神符，本生太阳河伯余。 本生太阳者，言水银本生太阳也。 太阳者，丹砂也，生於丙丁。 丙丁者，火精，上为荧惑星，下为丹砂也，故言生於丙丁。 丙丁居南方，为太阳，故易营虚日，南方为太阳。 太阳者，丹砂生於日，日生於火，火日之子。 北方壬癸为太阴，太阴者水也。 故易营虚月，北方生磁石。 磁石者，铅也。 其精上为北辰星，生坎。 坎位在北方，离位在南方。 河伯余者，水银也。 J 取水银多少自在，置赤土釜中，飞之九上九下，和以鲤鱼胆，复取水银多少自在，复封涂闭固如法，丹华法复九上九下，和以龙膏，名日神符。 其子四千相与俱者，谓曾青、矾石、戎盐、硫黄也，故言相与俱也。 河上妮女诚独妹，娥眉白易如明珠。 长沙好砂色由由，少小贞信不用夫。 束西南北父母俱，身不沾污清若珠。 好待贤士相待须，勇悍敢语言若书。 安心怀能才有余，不校人女妄吹嘘。 河上诧女者，铅黄华也。 子明媒之，使共居也。 贤士者，水银。 子明媒之使共居者，言取铅黄华一斤，置铁器中，以炭火之，即复取水银七斤，投铅中，猛火媪之，须央精华俱上出现，状若黄金紫赤，状若流星似流珠，五色玄黄，即以铁匕接以取之，得九一之斤，即三化九转，名曰丹黄之华，一名玄黄之洵，一名天地之符。 即以治汞化为丹，名曰还丹，乃名日仙药神丹。 圣人秘之，非凡俗道人所当见知，自非贤圣开通导达，殊人乃能知之。 故书不尽言，言不尽意也。 故经日：丹精生日精，光明也。 日子者，火也，故火名子明也。 水银亦名子朋，故易营虚日。 丹精生日，太阴生月，位在北方坎，其数一，故能知一万事毕。 一者，铅也。 铅精生月，铅精名太阴石。 一名金公，一名河车，一名河上姥女，一名立制石。 凡愚之人治药，反用山中立制石，非也。 去道万里。 真人自以铅黄华变化，立制石胆，皆出铅中。 凡愚民方士好事者治药，反用羌里石胆，非也，去道万里，治药由不成也。 真人自以丹砂精，化为流珠雪，霜铅精俱化为还丹，黄白乃成，服之神仙矣。 不用此二物治药，虽得丹服之，由复死矣。 太阴者，铅也。 太阳者，丹砂也。 太阴者坎位，在子。 太阳为离位，在午。 故坎生月，离生日也。 日为夫，月为妇也。 日为雄，月为雌也。 磁石铅属太阴，位在子，其数一。 丹砂属阳，位在午，其数九。 雄黄属土，其数五，故曰一五九，凡十五，故真人名为三五。 知三五横行天下。 能知三五，以治药为还丹，服之耳得长生不死，故曰横行天下。 故真人日：能知三奇六仪，何用余为。 丹砂为雄，铅为雌。 故传日：父三奇，母六仪，审知此道，何用封侯，为此之谓也。 子明媒之使共居者，言取水银九斤，铅一斤，合置赤土釜中，猛火上，从平旦至日落下时，水银与铅精皆俱出，如黄金色，名日玄黄精，一名黄芽，一名黄轻。

Then take one *zhu* of the elixir and grind it with one *jin* each of lead, tin, and mercury—all will transform into gold and silver. Thus it is said: "A *jin* for a *jin*, and one *zhu*—take care not to exceed this measure." Always at dawn, when the sun rises, face east, bow twice, kneel, and ingest it like grain. The superior adept who consumes it will ascend as an immortal among the Nine Sovereigns in seven days. The lesser adept will attain immortality in seventy days. The foolish who take it will achieve it only after a year.

When preparing the divine medicine and consuming it, one must first purify through fasting, bathing in five fragrant herbs, and observing the proper rites—without these, the medicine will not form. To refine the elixir in a cinnabar crucible with divine talismans is most excellent. Do not covet wealth; only by refining the divine medicine can one attain immortality. Do not transmit this recklessly.

The Perfected One said: The second elixir is called the Divine Talisman, born of the surplus of the Great Yang and the River Earl. "Born of the Great Yang" refers to mercury, which originates from the Great Yang. The Great Yang is cinnabar, born in *bing* and *ding*. *Bing* and *ding* are the essence of fire, ascending as the Star of Blazing Delusion and descending as cinnabar. Thus it is said to be born in *bing* and *ding*. *Bing* and *ding* reside in the south, the direction of the Great Yang. Therefore, the *Yi* speaks of the "empty sun" in the south as the Great Yang. The Great Yang is cinnabar, born of the sun, and the sun is born of fire—fire is the child of the sun.

The north, *ren* and *gui*, is the Great Yin, and the Great Yin is water. Thus the *Yi* speaks of the "empty moon" in the north, where lodestone is born. Lodestone is lead. Its essence ascends as the North Star, born in *kan*. *Kan* resides in the north, while *li* resides in the south. The "surplus of the River Earl" is mercury.

Take an unrestricted measure of mercury, place it in a red clay crucible, and refine it with nine ascents and nine descents, blending it with carp gall. Then take another unrestricted measure of mercury, seal and coat it securely as prescribed, and repeat the process of nine ascents and nine descents, blending it with dragon’s fat—this is called the Divine Talisman. Its four thousand companions are azurite, alum, halite, and sulfur, hence the saying "they accompany it together."

The River Maid, the solitary younger sister,
With brows like crescent moons and skin white as luminous pearls.
The cinnabar of Changsha, radiant in hue,
From youth steadfast and chaste, needing no husband.
East and west, north and south—her parents both present,
Her body untouched, pure as a pearl.
She awaits the worthy scholar who must seek her,
Bold and forthright, her words like scripture.
At peace, her talents overflow,
Never boasting falsely to others.

The "River Maid" is the yellow essence of lead. The "worthy scholar" is mercury. "You illuminate the matchmaker’s role, causing them to dwell together" means: take one *jin* of the yellow essence of lead, place it in an iron vessel, and heat it with charcoal. Then take seven *jin* of mercury and add it to the lead, firing it intensely. In an instant, their essences rise together, appearing like yellow-gold and purple-red, resembling shooting stars or flowing pearls, in hues of five colors and mysterious yellow. Use an iron spoon to gather it, obtaining nine *jin* of the one—this is the three transformations and nine revolutions, called the Flower of Cinnabar, also known as the Profound Yellow Essence or the Talisman of Heaven and Earth.

Refine mercury with this to form the elixir, called the Returning Cinnabar, or the Divine Elixir of Immortality. The sages guard this secret; it is not for ordinary Daoist practitioners to know. Only the wise and enlightened, those of exceptional insight, can comprehend it. Thus the texts do not exhaust their words, nor do words exhaust their meaning.

Therefore, the scripture says: "The essence of cinnabar gives birth to the essence of the sun—radiant and luminous." The "child of the sun" is fire, hence fire is called "Child Illuminator." Mercury is also called "Child Companion," as the *Yi* says. The essence of cinnabar gives birth to the sun, and the Great Yin gives birth to the moon. The moon’s position is in the north at *kan*, its number one—thus knowing the One, all things are complete. The One is lead. The essence of lead gives birth to the moon, and the essence of lead is called the Stone of the Great Yin. It is also named Metal Duke, River Chariot, Old Woman of the River, or Standing Regulator Stone.

Fools who prepare the medicine mistakenly use the Standing Regulator Stone from the mountains—this is wrong, a thousand miles from the Dao. The Perfected One transforms the yellow essence of lead into the Standing Regulator Stone and gall, all derived from lead. Foolish commoners, alchemists, and meddlers who prepare the medicine mistakenly use Qiangli gall—this is wrong, a thousand miles from the Dao, and their medicine will not form.

The Perfected One refines the essence of cinnabar into flowing pearls, frost, and snow, while the essence of lead transforms into the Returning Cinnabar. When yellow and white are achieved, consuming it grants immortality. Without these two substances in the preparation, even if one obtains the elixir and consumes it, they will still die.

The Great Yin is lead, and the Great Yang is cinnabar. The Great Yin is the position of *kan*, at *zi*. The Great Yang is the position of *li*, at *wu*. Thus *kan* gives birth to the moon, and *li* gives birth to the sun. The sun is the husband, the moon the wife. The sun is male, the moon female. Lodestone and lead belong to the Great Yin, positioned at *zi*, their number one. Cinnabar belongs to the Yang, positioned at *wu*, its number nine. Realgar belongs to earth, its number five. Thus it is said: one, five, nine—fifteen in total—hence the Perfected One calls it the Three-Five. Knowing the Three-Five, one may traverse the world. Those who know the Three-Five and prepare the Returning Cinnabar to consume will attain longevity and immortality—thus they traverse the world.

Therefore, the Perfected One said: "Knowing the Three Marvels and Six Harmonies, what need is there for anything else?" Cinnabar is the male, lead the female. Thus the tradition says: "The father is the Three Marvels, the mother the Six Harmonies. Master this Dao—what need is there for enfeoffment?" This is its meaning.

"You illuminate the matchmaker’s role, causing them to dwell together" means: take nine *jin* of mercury and one *jin* of lead, combine them in a red clay crucible, and fire them intensely from dawn until sunset. The mercury and the essence of lead will emerge together, golden in color—this is called the Profound Yellow Essence, also known as Yellow Sprout or Yellow Light.

chunks.original_text: 以丹华水之，名日黄池，一名黄华，一名黄龙，一名玄制石。 取玄黄和以玄水，令如封泥丸之，内赤土釜中，封以六一泥，内外厚三分，令乾十日，无令泄，以马通若糠火，火之八十一日，当庚辛。 庚辛者，黄金之名也。 真人秘之，不言黄金，故字金为庚辛。 取玄黄一刀圭，纳猛火中，以夹囊鼓炊之，饭顷皆消成庚辛。 不成庚辛，火之飞去药，生不可服也。 当纳赤土釜中，火之如前，封涂之，九九八十一日，药乃可用也。 玄黄一名伏丹，一名紫粉。 欲服之，常以甲子日平旦，束向日，再拜，服如小豆，日吞一丸，百日百病皆愈。 玄黄药治大癫大癞，百日皆愈，无所不治。 子明媒之使共居，与不相听欲上书，后复会面神丈夫。 欲上书者，水银未与铅和合也。 复会面神丈夫者，水银也。 子明迫之者，用火也。 子明迫用赤釜者，赤土釜也。 子明者，火也。 后竟相听色由由，言铅与水银合飞之，为玄黄也。 色由由者，药色殊好也。 夫从外来，妇从内来，鱼水相得，乃食行相须。 四时生子若神庐，五色光颜厚寸余，言雌雄相得，不复飞去也。 即复取玄黄，和以百日华池，令如泥，以直两赤釜裹及外，内厚三分，因纳水银三斤於其中，亦可纳十斤水银，作药多少自在，飞三斤水银，可以飞一人耳，令一人得道仙去，其药少故也。 飞一斤可得十两。 飞玄黄耳，言取一斤水银，纳赤土釜中，覆以玄黄，其上厚二寸，所以一土釜合之，封涂以六一泥，如治丹华法，以马通糠火，火之九日九夜，水银皆飞上着釜裹，状如雪霜，紫赤鸿生五色也，故言五色光颜厚寸余，以毛羽扫取之，和以黄戍，若复如初也。 黄戍者，黄狗胆也。 若和以河伯余者，鲤鱼胆也。 即取鲤鱼胆，和飞雪霜者，水银飞精合如封书，泥丸之，复纳赤土釜中，复以玄黄精覆之，厚一寸，以一赤土釜合盖之，以六一泥封涂釜口际会，无令泄，置日中曝之十日，大乾燥，乃可塭之。 塭者，不可烧也。 稍热釜坼也，失大药也。 复火之九日九夜，可止。 后一日寒，发之，以羽毛扫取上飞精鸿紫，名日神符还丹。 和以龙膏，丸如小豆，常以平旦束向日，再拜长跪，服之百日，与诸神仙玉女相随，从诸神行如飞也。 欲渡江河海，以神符丹和以龙胆膏，若鲤鱼胆，涂两足下，以渡江海河淮渭济，以行水上，足不濡者，不溺没，故言足不濡。 得道度世，百病除身，得不死，无百病也。 服药百日，腹中三虫三尸，皆自坏败死下也。 土龙鱼胆，皆阴精也。 水银者，阳精也。 故阴能制阳，为药伏不敢起也。 真人神人仙人秘不得传。 真人日：第三之丹名神丹，五色参差诚可观。 本自正阳武都闲者，言真雄黄、雌黄，皆出正阳武都。 武阳亦有雄黄，洁诤白，面又大。 神者言八石之中，雄黄、雌黄辟五兵，治百病，尤大神良。 洁净白面者，取鲜好者也。 常得贤士两万钱者，言能飞雄雌，得其飞精一刀圭，价直万钱。 面色较好目墦者，言飞雄雌药，生五色好也。 晨昏夜暮出游止名山者，言以火飞精在上釜，故言止名山。 方士劫之不敢焉，言道人以赤土釜二枚合飞之，不敢者，不令其飞精去。 取下土石也，取其飞精也。 言法取雄黄二斤，雌黄一斤，凡三斤，小以华池传药，乃不敢散飞去华池者。

Take the Cinnabar Blossom and infuse it with water—this is called Yellow Pool, also known as Yellow Blossom, Yellow Dragon, or Dark-Restraining Stone. Combine the Profound Yellow with Dark Water, shaping it like a sealed-clay pellet, and place it in a red clay crucible. Seal it with Six-One Mud, both inside and out, to a thickness of three *fen*, then let it dry for ten days without leakage. Fire it with horse dung or chaff for eighty-one days, coinciding with *geng-xin*. *Geng-xin* is the name for yellow gold. The Perfected One guarded this secret, never speaking of "yellow gold," hence writing "gold" as *geng-xin*. Take one *dao-gui* of Profound Yellow and place it in intense fire, fanning it with a bellows until, in the time it takes to cook a meal, it all transforms into *geng-xin*. If it fails to become *geng-xin*, the fire will cause the medicine to fly away, and the raw substance cannot be consumed. Return it to the red clay crucible, fire it as before, seal and coat it, and after eighty-one days, the medicine will be ready for use.

Profound Yellow is also called Hidden Cinnabar or Purple Powder. To consume it, always at dawn on a *jia-zi* day, face east toward the sun, bow twice, and swallow a pellet the size of a small bean. Take one pill daily, and after a hundred days, all illnesses will be cured. The Profound Yellow medicine cures severe leprosy and scabies, healing all ailments within a hundred days—there is nothing it cannot treat.

"You illuminate the matchmaker’s role, causing them to dwell together, yet they refuse to listen and wish to petition" refers to mercury not yet harmonized with lead. "Later, they meet the divine husband again" refers to the mercury. "You press them" means applying fire. "You press them with the red crucible" means the red clay crucible. "You" refers to fire. "Eventually, they listen to each other, their hues radiant" describes lead and mercury combining and flying together to form Profound Yellow. "Radiant hues" means the medicine’s color is exceptionally fine.

"The husband comes from without, the wife from within; like fish and water, they attain harmony and depend on each other." "In the four seasons, they bear offspring like divine huts, their five-colored glow over an inch thick" means that when the male and female essences unite, they no longer fly away. Then, take the Profound Yellow, blend it with the Hundred-Day Blossom Pool until it resembles mud, and coat the inside and outside of two red clay crucibles to a thickness of three *fen*. Place three *jin* of mercury within—up to ten *jin* may be used, depending on the desired quantity of medicine. Flying three *jin* of mercury suffices for one person’s transcendence, as the medicine is potent. Flying one *jin* yields ten *liang*.

To fly the Profound Yellow: take one *jin* of mercury, place it in a red clay crucible, and cover it with Profound Yellow to a depth of two *cun*. Seal it with another red clay crucible, coating the joint with Six-One Mud as in the Cinnabar Blossom method. Fire it with horse dung or chaff for nine days and nights, and the mercury will all fly upward, adhering to the crucible’s interior like frost or snow, shimmering in purple, red, and five colors—hence the description of a five-colored glow over an inch thick. Brush it off with a feather, then blend it with Yellow *Shu*. If repeating the process, Yellow *Shu* is the gall of a yellow dog. Alternatively, blend it with the River Earl’s Remnant, which is carp gall. Take the carp gall and mix it with the flying frost-and-snow (the mercury’s flying essence), forming a seal like a clay pellet. Return it to a red clay crucible, cover it again with Profound Yellow Essence to a depth of one *cun*, and seal it with another red clay crucible. Coat the joint with Six-One Mud to prevent leakage, then place it in the sun for ten days to thoroughly dry. Only then may it be fired.

Firing must not be done hastily, lest the crucible crack and the great medicine be lost. Fire it again for nine days and nights, then stop. After cooling for a day, open it and brush off the flying essence—crimson and purple—called the Divine Talisman Returning Cinnabar. Blend it with Dragon Grease, forming pellets the size of small beans. At dawn, face east toward the sun, bow twice, kneel, and consume it. After a hundred days, you will be accompanied by divine immortals and jade maidens, moving with the gods as swiftly as flight. To cross rivers and seas, mix the Divine Talisman Cinnabar with Dragon Gall Grease or carp gall, and apply it to the soles of your feet. You may traverse the Yangtze, Yellow River, Huai, Wei, or Ji without wetting your feet or drowning—hence the saying, "feet remain dry." Attaining the Dao and transcending the world, all illnesses leave the body, granting deathlessness and freedom from all ailments.

After consuming the medicine for a hundred days, the Three Worms and Three Corpses in the abdomen will all decay and perish. Earth Dragon and fish gall are both yin essences, while mercury is yang essence. Thus, yin can restrain yang, rendering the medicine docile and preventing it from rising. The Perfected, the Divine, and the Immortals guard this secret and do not transmit it.

The Perfected One said: "The third elixir is called Divine Cinnabar, its five colors intermingled—truly a sight to behold." It originates from the true yang of Wudu’s seclusion, referring to true realgar and orpiment, both produced in Zhengyang Wudu. Wuyang also yields realgar, pure and white, with a fine texture. "Divine" means that among the Eight Stones, realgar and orpiment repel weapons, cure all illnesses, and are especially potent. "Pure and white" refers to selecting the finest specimens. "A worthy man’s value is twenty thousand coins" means that flying realgar and orpiment yields a flying essence worth ten thousand coins per *dao-gui*. "Their complexions fair, their eyes bright" describes the flying medicine of realgar and orpiment, producing five splendid colors. "Roaming at dawn and dusk, halting at famous mountains" refers to the flying essence adhering to the upper crucible—hence "halting at famous mountains." "Alchemists dare not seize it" means that the Daoist uses two red clay crucibles to fly the essence, ensuring it does not escape. "Take the lower earth and stone" means collecting the flying essence. The method: take two *jin* of realgar and one *jin* of orpiment, totaling three *jin*. First, soak the medicine in the Blossom Pool to prevent it from scattering and flying away.

chunks.original_text: 百日酝取雄雌，合纳铁臼中，治之万杵，合和如粉，纳赤土釜中，盖以玄黄粉，上下左右各厚一寸，以六一泥封涂，无令泄，曝乾之十日，乃可以马通火，飞之九日九夜，火去釜边五寸，以火壅之九日九夜，推火至釜下，猛其火九日九夜，以火壅之，至釜半火之，复九日九夜，可四九三十六日。 后一日寒发，以鸡羽毛扫取飞，和以龙膏，复飞之如前治丹华法，火之三九二十七日止。 后一日寒之发，以鸡羽毛扫取之，名日飞精，即治以为药，名日神丹。 道士服之，即神仙，亦不过百日仙矣，下愚服之，一年乃仙去。 非有鬼神药使然。 凡人男女俗人小儿，服药皆神仙，服之击之皆大神。 子明合会使相亲，子明者，火使相亲也。 雄雌合得火飞精，善涂其际致令坚。 以六一泥涂土釜内外上下，各厚三分。 先以玄黄和以华池，令如泥，以涂两赤土釜裹，无令泄，故言致令坚。 牡蛎、赤石脂、磁石凡三物，分各等，治之万杵，令如粉，和以左味。 先以华池平均其中，令不津不泄，取上飞雄雌黄精，和以龙膏物相因，言治九丹神药飞精，不得龙膏药不神。 故言和以龙膏物相因，食之不死寿万年也。 坐使诸神，言服神丹百日，诸仙下迎，真人玉女玉童，素女青腰，诸百鬼山卿泽尉，皆来侍从道人度世，无种事在人耳，奴婢鸡狗，皆可得仙，凡人服药亦皆然。 居必僻处，言欲服神丹，当居深山石室中，大泽中，近水涯谷空宅也。 慎无与俗问愚人通语，言作药无令拓嫉人，多口人，不好道人知也。 无与葬埋、娶妇、嫁女家通。 常独卧一室中，神仙玉女必来降。 敬畏神者，言服神丹，天神仙人玉女来下，人必恭敬事之，深思天道，无敢懈息，常居石室，依名山者，欲合药服药，当深里大泽无人之处，亦非俗人所当见知也。 必居深山岩石问，能得神丹，皆升天。 神丹既成，举家仙矣。 百官鸡犬青云问，世皆历盛去甚难，言世人贪财，不肯合神药，反服草药导引，因复死不寿矣，故言去甚难。 夫草药可以治人百病，不能使人长生久寿。 何以言之，夫草药埋之即腐，煮之即焦，故草不能自生，何能使人长生乎。 真人曰：第四之丹名还丹，男子兄弟通九人。 九人者，言药凡有九物，以为土釜，以为直也。 取誉石、矾石、代赭、戎盐、牡蛎、赤石脂、土龙疾、云母、滑石，凡九物。 皆烧之一日一夜，猛其火，皆梼治令如粉，和以酝，令如泥，以用直涂土釜裹内外，各厚五分，令阴乾十日。 即纳水银土釜中，以雄黄覆其上，次以曾青，次以矾石，次以硫黄，次以卤咸，次以太一禹余粮，次以誉石，誉石独在上。 凡七物各异治之，令如粉。 水银一斤，独在下，余次第之，釜合上。 即以六一泥和善酝，封涂其际，勿令泄，曝乾之十日。 即置铁五柱上，令高九寸，以马通或糠火媪，去土釜底五寸，微其火，九日九夜。 复增火至金半，复九日九夜。 常以濡布加覆釜上，令药不飞亡。 布乾辄复濡之。 如治丹华法，凡九九八十一日，药成皆飞上着，生五色，即以鸡羽扫取之，合以百草华，以井华水，服一刀圭，卧石室中，令人不饥渴，百岁。 渴饮石泉，饥则少食枣栗二十枚，静处思神药。 日一服，服药百日，朱雀凤凰翔其上，玉女至。

After steeping realgar and orpiment for a hundred days, combine them and place in an iron mortar, grinding ten thousand strokes until they become a fine powder. Transfer this into a red clay crucible, covering it with a layer of *xuanhuang* powder one *cun* thick on all sides—top, bottom, and around. Seal with *liuyi* mud to prevent leakage, then dry in the sun for ten days. Next, use horse dung as fuel to fly the medicine for nine days and nine nights, keeping the fire five *cun* from the crucible’s edge. Then, intensify the fire for another nine days and nine nights, gradually moving it beneath the crucible. Strengthen the fire further for nine days and nine nights, then raise it to the crucible’s midpoint, continuing for another nine days and nine nights—totaling thirty-six days in four cycles of nine.

On the following day, allow it to cool before opening. Sweep the flying essence with a chicken feather, mix it with dragon fat, and fly it again following the method for refining *danhua*. Fire it for three cycles of nine, twenty-seven days in all. The next day, let it cool and open it, sweeping the essence with a chicken feather. This is called *flying essence*, which, when refined into medicine, is named *divine elixir*. When Daoists consume it, they become immortals, achieving transcendence in no more than a hundred days. Even the foolish, if they take it, will ascend in a year—not through the work of ghosts or spirits.

Men and women, common folk and children—all who consume this medicine become immortals. Those who take it and strike it become great spirits. *Ziming* harmonizes the union, for *Ziming* is the fire that unites them. When realgar and orpiment combine with fire to produce flying essence, carefully seal the seams to ensure firmness. Coat the inner and outer surfaces of the red clay crucible with *liuyi* mud, each layer three *fen* thick. First, mix *xuanhuang* with the Blossom Pool liquid to a mud-like consistency, then apply it to both red clay crucibles, ensuring no leakage—this is what is meant by "ensuring firmness."

Take oyster shell, red halloysite, and magnetite—three substances in equal parts—grind each ten thousand strokes into powder, and blend with *zuowei*. First, evenly distribute the Blossom Pool liquid within to prevent moisture or leakage. Then, take the flying essence of realgar and orpiment, mix it with dragon fat, and let the ingredients interact. This refers to refining the nine divine elixirs and flying essence; without dragon fat, the medicine lacks potency. Thus, it is said, "mix with dragon fat and let the ingredients interact," and consuming it grants immortality and longevity for ten thousand years.

It is said that after consuming the divine elixir for a hundred days, all spirits descend to welcome you: perfected beings, jade maidens, jade lads, the White Maiden, and the Azure Waist, along with the hundred ghosts of mountains, marsh officials, and marsh wardens—all come to serve the Daoist and guide them to transcendence. There is no inherent distinction; even slaves, maidservants, chickens, and dogs can attain immortality. All who consume the medicine achieve this.

One must dwell in seclusion: to take the divine elixir, reside in a mountain cave, a stone chamber, a great marsh, near a riverside valley, or an empty dwelling. Be cautious not to converse with worldly fools—do not let those who gossip or envy, or those who dislike the Dao, learn of your work. Avoid contact with households involved in burials, weddings, or betrothals. Always sleep alone in a chamber, and the immortal jade maidens will surely descend.

Revere the spirits: when consuming the divine elixir, heavenly spirits, immortals, and jade maidens descend. One must serve them with reverence, contemplate the celestial Dao without negligence, and dwell in a stone chamber near a famous mountain. To refine and consume the elixir, choose a deep marsh or uninhabited place, unseen by worldly eyes. Only by residing in mountain caves and rocky seclusion can one obtain the divine elixir and ascend to heaven. Once the divine elixir is complete, the entire household becomes immortal. Officials, chickens, and dogs rise amid the azure clouds—yet in the world, such prosperity is rare and departure difficult. Worldly people, greedy for wealth, refuse to refine the divine elixir, instead consuming herbal medicines and practicing *daoyin*, only to die without longevity. Thus, departure is exceedingly difficult.

Herbal medicines can cure a hundred illnesses but cannot grant long life or immortality. Why? Herbs rot when buried and char when boiled; if they cannot preserve themselves, how can they grant humans longevity? The Perfected One said: The fourth elixir is called *Returning Elixir*, and nine brothers may share it. The "nine" refers to the nine substances used to line the crucible. Take stalactite, alum, hematite, halite, oyster shell, red halloysite, *tulongji*, mica, and talc—nine substances in all. Burn each for a day and a night with intense fire, then grind them into powder. Mix with fermented liquid to a mud-like consistency and use it to coat the inner and outer surfaces of the clay crucible, each layer five *fen* thick. Let it dry in the shade for ten days.

Then place mercury in the crucible, cover it with realgar, followed by azurite, alum, sulfur, bittern, *taiyi yuyuliang*, and stalactite—with stalactite alone on top. Each of the seven substances is processed separately into powder. Place one *jin* of mercury at the bottom, layering the rest in order. Seal the crucible with *liuyi* mud mixed with fine fermented liquid, ensuring no leakage, and dry in the sun for ten days. Place it on five iron pillars, nine *cun* high, and heat with horse dung or chaff fire, keeping it five *cun* from the crucible’s base. Maintain a gentle fire for nine days and nine nights, then increase the fire to the crucible’s midpoint for another nine days and nine nights. Continuously cover the crucible with damp cloth to prevent the medicine from flying away; rewet the cloth when it dries. Following the method for refining *danhua*, after eighty-one days in nine cycles of nine, the medicine will ascend and adhere, forming five colors. Sweep it with a chicken feather, mix with a hundred flower essences and well water, and consume one *dao-gui*. Lie in a stone chamber, and one will no longer hunger or thirst for a hundred years. When thirsty, drink from a stone spring; when hungry, eat twenty dates or chestnuts. Remain tranquil and contemplate the divine medicine. Take it once daily, and after a hundred days, vermilion phoenixes will soar above you, and jade maidens will arrive.

chunks.original_text: 服药二百日，仙人与俱游。 服之一年，太一迎之。 以还丹涂钱用市物，钱皆自还。 丹书目眶卧，恶鬼皆走去。 一刀圭粉，水银一斤，火之立成黄金。 当用龙膏和之，九日九夜，乃成真黄金矣。 九转流珠神仙九丹经卷上竟 九转流珠神仙九丹经卷下 太清真人述 真人神水法 真人日：第五之丹名日饵丹，自长沙武陵士，太一旬石朱氏子。 氏子者，水银也。 武陵士者，雄黄也。 太一旬石者，禹余根也。 法取水银一斤，雄黄一斤，治之如粉，加水银上。 禹余根一斤，治之如粉，加雄黄上。 纳土釜中，以一釜合之口际，封以六一泥，令乾燥，以马通或糠火之，九日九夜，更以炭火之，九日九夜，药皆飞着土釜上。 子明媒之与贤士者，子明火也，贤士者黄金。 俱与水银，合入天雄，和以龙膏、少室人雄分各等。 神爵子者，鸡子也。 服一刀圭，忽然万里仙去，渡江海也。 服之不久三旬者，三十日能飞矣。 诸神往来卫左右者，万神侍从皆事己，玉女青腰皆可使，乘自然之车，上升天也。 从玉女，天下之神皆事己，百神墟里社稷，风伯雨师诸神，皆来事己。 故名第五之丹母，一名饵丹也。 真人曰：第六之丹名炼丹，所出微妙诸神仙。 乃出蛮夷巴越问者，言越砂出巴郡越乡。 目如珠光口如丹者，取其鲜明者也。 贤者不取人民问者，取土龙膏，飞流八石。 三旬问者，飞石三十日。 八石者，巴砂、越砂、雄黄、雌黄、曾青、矾石、磁石、石胆，凡八物分等作药，多少自在，和以龙膏、土龙侯一斗，以和黄犬胆，合土龙侯二斗，以为釜。 牡蛎、赤石脂各三斤，以左味涎牡蛎、赤石脂治如粉。 左味者，大米酦也。 和为泥，涂土釜内外，厚三分。 子明和调，令可丸，小火以泥涂釜际，无令泄。 八石当飞，上着如雪霜，言其精色如雪霜，言和以龙膏，物相因者，丸如小豆，亦可服食。 黄白成，言药成可作金银，诸神敬诺听己言也，百鬼神皆可使，服之后饭者十日也。 非独男子，女子亦然。 女子服之，亦飞仙。 辟谷不食者，绝五谷，但饮水绝念。 若与妇女交通，道必不成。 作药不食糖苦捐，如身涂污，去之难治。 八石各异治之如粉，巴砂、越砂在下，次以雄黄，次以雌黄，次以曾青，次以矾石，次以石胆，次以磁石，磁石在上，以一土釜合之，以六一泥封合两釜，牡蛎赤石脂涂合际，飞之以马通或糠火，火之如治丹华法，飞之三旬，取飞精，和以龙膏，丸如小豆，食后服之下滓，可以治百病，神验也。 真人曰：第七之丹名柔丹，与饵丹相似，滑泽又易食。 水银三斤，先以玄黄和左味令如泥，以涂釜内外，厚三分。 纳水银其中，封以六一泥，无令泄。 乾十日，飞之如丹华法，二十日止。 取上飞精，和以龙膏，则欲求子，和以缺盆。 九十老公服之，阳气大强，可复生子。 以柔丹尽神木为人神，木者梧桐也。 以柔丹字奴婢，不敢逃亡。 八十老母服之，即复生子。 长吏服之，即时升迁。

After two hundred days of consuming the medicine, immortals will accompany you on your journeys. After one year, the Great One will come to receive you. If you use the returned elixir to coat coins for market transactions, the coins will all return to you. If you write with the elixir on your eyelids while lying down, evil spirits will all flee. One *dao-gui* of powder mixed with a catty of mercury, when fired, immediately transforms into yellow gold. *The Scripture of the Nine Cycles of Flowing Pearls and the Nine Elixirs of Divine Immortals, Scroll the Lower.*
*Transmitted by the Perfected One of Great Clarity*

The Perfected One’s Divine Water Method:
The Perfected One said: The fifth elixir is called *Er Dan* ("Edible Elixir"). It originated with a scholar from Wuling in Changsha, a man of the Taiyi Xunshi and the Zhu clan. The "man of the Zhu clan" refers to mercury. The "scholar from Wuling" refers to realgar. The "Taiyi Xunshi" refers to *yuyugen* (limonite). Take one catty of mercury and one catty of realgar, grind them into powder, and place the mercury on top. Take one catty of *yuyugen*, grind it into powder, and place it atop the realgar. Seal them in an earthen crucible, joining two crucibles at their mouths and sealing them with Six-One Mud. Allow it to dry, then fire it with horse dung or chaff for nine days and nine nights. Then refine it with charcoal fire for another nine days and nine nights, and the medicine will all ascend and adhere to the upper crucible. *Ziming* is the catalyst, and the "worthy scholar" is gold. Both are combined with mercury, mixed with *tianxiong* (aconite), and blended with dragon’s fat and equal parts of Shaoshi human male essence.

The "Divine Sparrow Child" refers to a chicken egg. Consuming one *dao-gui* will suddenly transport you ten thousand *li* away, allowing you to cross rivers and seas. If taken for no more than thirty days, one will gain the ability to fly within that time. All spirits will come and go to guard your left and right, with ten thousand spirits attending and serving you. Jade maidens and green-waisted attendants will be at your command. You will ride a spontaneous chariot and ascend to heaven. Accompanied by jade maidens, all the gods of the world will serve you, and the spirits of the hundred deities, village altars, and state sacrifices—along with the Wind Earl and Rain Master—will all come to attend you. Thus, it is called the "Fifth Elixir, the Mother," and is also named *Er Dan*.

The Perfected One said: The sixth elixir is called *Lian Dan* ("Refined Elixir"), which is subtly wondrous and revered by all divine immortals. It comes from the distant lands of the Man and Yi tribes in Ba and Yue. It is said that Yue cinnabar originates from the Yue countryside in Ba Commandery. Choose specimens with eyes like pearls and mouths like cinnabar—those that are fresh and bright. The worthy do not take it from among the people; instead, they use earthworm fat and the flying essence of the Eight Stones. For thirty days, the stones are refined for thirty days. The Eight Stones are: Ba cinnabar, Yue cinnabar, realgar, orpiment, *zengqing* (azurite), alum, magnetite, and chalcanthite. Combine equal parts of these eight substances as the medicine, adjusting quantities as needed. Blend them with dragon’s fat and one *dou* of earthworm fat, then mix with the gallbladder of a yellow dog and two *dou* of earthworm fat to form the crucible. Use three catties each of oyster shell and red halloysite, grinding them into powder with left-flavored saliva. The "left flavor" refers to fermented rice liquid. Mix them into a mud and coat the inside and outside of the earthen crucible to a thickness of three *fen*. Harmonize *Ziming* and adjust until it can be formed into pills. Use a small fire and seal the crucible’s seams with mud to prevent leakage. When the Eight Stones ascend, they will adhere like frost and snow, their essence and color resembling such. Blend them with dragon’s fat, and the resulting pills will be the size of small beans, suitable for consumption. Once the yellow and white (gold and silver) are formed, the medicine is complete and can be used to create gold and silver. All spirits will respectfully heed your commands, and the hundred ghosts and gods will all be at your service. After consuming it, one may fast for ten days. Not only men but women may also take it. Women who consume it will likewise become flying immortals. To practice grain avoidance, one must abstain from the Five Grains and drink only water, eliminating all distracting thoughts. If one engages in sexual relations with women, the Dao will certainly not be achieved. When preparing the medicine, avoid sweetness, bitterness, and regret, for if the body becomes tainted, it will be difficult to remedy.

Grind each of the Eight Stones separately into powder. Place Ba cinnabar and Yue cinnabar at the bottom, followed by realgar, then orpiment, then *zengqing*, then alum, then chalcanthite, and finally magnetite at the top. Seal them in an earthen crucible, joining two crucibles and sealing them with Six-One Mud. Coat the seams with oyster shell and red halloysite, then refine them with horse dung or chaff fire, following the method for refining *danhua*. Refine them for thirty days, collect the ascended essence, blend it with dragon’s fat, and form pills the size of small beans. Consume them after meals, and the residue can be used to treat all illnesses, with divine efficacy.

The Perfected One said: The seventh elixir is called *Rou Dan* ("Supple Elixir"), which resembles *Er Dan* but is smoother and easier to consume. Take three catties of mercury, first blend it with *xuanhuang* (mysterious yellow) and left-flavored liquid to form a mud, and coat the inside and outside of the crucible to a thickness of three *fen*. Place the mercury inside, seal it with Six-One Mud, and ensure no leakage. Allow it to dry for ten days, then refine it following the method for *danhua* for twenty days. Collect the ascended essence and blend it with dragon’s fat. If one desires children, blend it with *quepen* (broken basin herb). When a ninety-year-old man consumes it, his yang qi will greatly strengthen, and he may father children again. If one uses *Rou Dan* to anoint the spirit tablets of ancestral spirits, the tablets will become imbued with divine power. If one writes with *Rou Dan* on the bodies of servants, they will not dare to flee. When an eighty-year-old woman consumes it, she may bear children again. When an official consumes it, he will be promptly promoted.

chunks.original_text: 治药法，飞之如丹华法，圣人斋戒成大神。 理人者，真人也。 不斋戒，药不神。 当求河女以为婚姻，当得名铅。 河女水银，与铅合精，可作金银，转相成就，生子孙者，药无不成，生无不化，令人不死，又可神仙矣。 真人曰：第八之丹名曰伏丹，其色颇黑紫，且姻五彩色集，可拘鬼却奸人。 以丹书门户，杀恶鬼，辟盗贼。 作之法，以赤土釜，若龙疾釜一枚，直以玄黄华，若铅釜中外，厚三分，封以六一泥，无令泄。 内水银釜中，封之令乾，以马通或糠火之，九日九夜。 以上釜为下釜，复飞之九日九夜。 复以下釜为上釜，如是九上九下，药成发取上飞精，和以龙膏，复飞之一旬。 上飞者治之如粉，盛以金银莆中，若生竹莆中。 常用平旦束向，再拜长跪，以井华水，服一刀圭，可神仙。 如枣核大者，着手巾中，百鬼消灭，不敢近人，魂魄坚强，独处石室，坐致神仙，虎狼自避。 妇人独守，持如大豆者，百鬼皆去，盗贼不敢来。 作药法，以水银一斤，多少自在，封闭如丹法，以六一泥涂，以两土釜亦可，用玄黄釜，亦可用洛阳赤土釜，胡粉釜，大小自在。 和以龙膏，飞之三日，取上着者，色如雪。 复以龙膏和久一旬，一旬者十日。 药成，如治丹华法，四子共养一母，曾青、磁石、誉石、玄黄为直，覆头上也。 真人曰：第九之丹名曰寒丹，法以金银为主，用金银为金。 五药集者，五石分等。 五石者，水银外雄黄、雌黄、曾青、誉石、磁石。 凡五神各一斤，水银二斤，异治，五神合粉之。 先纳水银釜中。 先直以玄黄，乃纳流珠釜中，次以雄黄布水银上，次以雌黄，次以曾青，次以誉石，次以磁石，磁石最在上。 以一土釜合之，封以六一泥，无令泄。 龙展黄土各半升，合为泥，去其土，先以牡砺、赤石脂泥涂釜际，厚三分合。 复以龙侯黄土，涂其上，厚三分。 令乾十日，以子明调之，微其火，神药当上着，正如锺乳。 火之九日九夜，寒发取上药，用雄鸡羽扫，和以龙膏若黄狗胆。 服之轻身，百日病悉愈。 青腰常侍使，玉女司命，着籍仙人渊府，言服还丹百日，削去生人死籍，名着仙录，出入无问，不可拘制，坐在立亡，能轻举飞上天，一时万里乘浮云，弃捐妻子，不复还焉。 第九丹法，如治丹华法也。 土釜皆同，封闭皆同，泥涂火皆同法，火常先文后武者。 先微其火，九日后小猛之，釜涂欲极乾燥，久久益善。 火之釜有坼如发者，药飞去。 治诸泥药，皆欲熟令如粉，下细筛。 如欲调左味者善。 大米醉，一名华池。 常以五月五日，七月七日，不如五月五日，独取最良。 龙膏液及龙膏泽，桑上露。 欲取之时，以绵拭之，绞取汁。 九鼎者，九丹也。 八十一首由一丹，能得之者升太清。 因火变化药自然，物类相使转相因。 水火之道最甚神，曾祖九族水为先。 金木合符夫妻身，日月星辰托阴阳。 谓精集会火为王，姓为陵阳字子明。 攻击胡虏诛豪强，延及巴越侵豫章。 四夷来降合中央，三阴相制柔胜强。 青龙白虎束西翔，凤凰朱雀赫瞳瞳。 黄金之楼十二重，中有玄武神龟倡。 五彩为帷覆玉房，真人御之升九皇。 游遨太清及明堂，精华踊跃如雪霜，能知此药为仙王。 真人曰：华盖者，铅黄华也。 雄黄入者，可覆雄仙药也。

The method for refining the elixir follows the *danhua* process, and the sage who observes purification rites will attain great divinity. Those who govern others are true persons. Without purification rites, the elixir will lack divine power. One must seek the River Maiden for marriage to obtain named lead. The River Maiden is mercury, which, when united with lead in essence, can produce gold and silver, mutually perfecting one another. For those who wish to bear descendants, no elixir will fail to form, and no transformation will remain unachieved. It grants immortality and the attainment of transcendence.

The True Person said: The eighth elixir is called *Fudan* (Subduing Elixir), its color a deep blackish-purple, yet it gathers the five hues. It can restrain ghosts and repel villains. When written with this elixir on doors and gates, it slays malevolent spirits and wards off thieves. The method for its preparation: use a red earthen crucible or a *longji* crucible, coating the inside and outside with *xuanhuang* or lead to a thickness of three *fen*. Seal it with Six-One Mud, ensuring no leakage. Place mercury inside the crucible, seal it, and allow it to dry. Refine it with horse dung or chaff fire for nine days and nine nights. Then, invert the crucible so the upper becomes the lower, and refine it again for nine days and nine nights. Repeat this inversion nine times, alternating upper and lower, until the elixir is complete. Collect the ascended essence, blend it with dragon’s fat, and refine it again for ten days. The ascended portion, when processed, resembles powder. Store it in a vessel of gold, silver, or fresh bamboo. At dawn, face east, bow twice, kneel, and consume one *daogui* with well-water drawn at dawn. This grants transcendence. A piece the size of a jujube pit, carried in one’s headscarf, will cause all ghosts to vanish and dare not approach. It strengthens the hun and po souls, allowing one to dwell alone in a stone chamber and attain transcendence. Tigers and wolves will naturally avoid one. If a woman lives alone and holds a piece the size of a soybean, all ghosts will depart, and thieves will not dare approach.

The method for preparing the elixir: take one *jin* of mercury, adjusting the quantity as desired. Seal it following the *dan* method, coating with Six-One Mud. Two earthen crucibles may be used, or a crucible coated with *xuanhuang*, or a Luoyang red earthen crucible, or a lead-powder crucible, with size adjusted as needed. Blend with dragon’s fat and refine for three days. Collect the ascended portion, which will be snow-white. Blend it again with dragon’s fat for ten days. When the elixir is complete, process it as in the *danhua* method. Four agents nurture one mother: *cengqing*, magnetite, *yushi*, and *xuanhuang* are placed atop it.

The True Person said: The ninth elixir is called *Handan* (Cold Elixir). Its method takes gold and silver as the foundation, using them as the primary metal. The five agents gather in equal measure. The five minerals are mercury, realgar, orpiment, *cengqing*, *yushi*, and magnetite. Take one *jin* each of the five divine agents and two *jin* of mercury, processing them separately. Grind the five agents into powder and place them in the crucible. First coat the crucible with *xuanhuang*, then add *liuzhu* (flowing pearls) to the crucible. Layer realgar over the mercury, followed by orpiment, *cengqing*, *yushi*, and magnetite, with magnetite on top. Seal two earthen crucibles together with Six-One Mud, ensuring no leakage. Mix equal parts dragon’s saliva and yellow earth to form mud, then remove the earth. First coat the crucible’s seams with *muli* and *chishizhi* mud to a thickness of three *fen*, then coat the exterior with dragon’s saliva and yellow earth to the same thickness. Allow it to dry for ten days. Refine it with *Ziming*’s method, using gentle fire. The divine elixir will ascend and adhere like stalactites. Refine it for nine days and nine nights, then collect the ascended elixir, sweeping it with a rooster’s feather. Blend it with dragon’s fat or the gallbladder of a yellow dog. Consuming it lightens the body, and after a hundred days, all illnesses are cured. The Azure Waist Attendant commands, and the Jade Maiden of Destiny records one’s name in the registers of the transcendent’s abyssal palace. It is said that consuming the Returning Elixir for a hundred days erases one’s name from the ledgers of the living and the dead, inscribing it in the records of immortals. One may come and go without question, unbound by restraints, able to vanish while seated or standing. It grants the power to ascend and fly to the heavens, traversing ten thousand *li* in an instant upon floating clouds. One may abandon wife and children, never to return.

The method for the ninth elixir follows the *danhua* process. The earthen crucibles, sealing, mud coating, and firing methods are all the same. The fire should begin gently and later intensify. For the first nine days, use gentle fire, then increase its strength. The crucible’s coating must be thoroughly dried, and the longer it is fired, the better. If the crucible cracks like a hair, the elixir will escape. When processing all mud-based elixirs, grind them thoroughly into fine powder and sift them. Mixing with *zuowei* is beneficial. *Dami* wine is also called the Flowery Pool. It is best gathered on the fifth day of the fifth month or the seventh day of the seventh month, though the fifth day of the fifth month is optimal. Dragon’s fat and dragon’s saliva are the dew on mulberry leaves. To collect them, wipe with silk and wring out the liquid.

The Nine Tripods are the nine elixirs. Eighty-one chapters derive from one elixir; those who attain it ascend to the Great Clarity. Through fire, the elixir transforms naturally, with agents mutually aiding and depending on one another. The Dao of water and fire is most divine. The ancestors of the nine clans begin with water. Metal and wood unite as husband and wife, while the sun, moon, and stars rely on yin and yang. When essence gathers, fire reigns supreme. My surname is Lingyang, and my style is Ziming. I strike down the Hu barbarians and punish the powerful, extending my reach to Ba and Yue, encroaching upon Yuzhang. The four barbarians submit and unite at the center. The three yin forces restrain one another, and the soft overcomes the strong. The Azure Dragon and White Tiger soar east and west, while the Vermilion Phoenix and Scarlet Bird blaze brilliantly. The twelve-tiered tower of gold holds within it the Dark Warrior, the divine tortoise leading the chorus. Five-colored curtains drape the jade chamber, where the True Person ascends to the Nine Emperors. Roaming the Great Clarity and the Hall of Light, their radiant essence leaps forth like snow and frost. Those who know this elixir become lords of immortals.

The True Person said: The *Huagai* (Canopy) is the yellow essence of lead. When realgar is added, it can cover the elixir of male transcendents.

chunks.original_text: 铅为华盖，谓神水也，故言铅黄华。 夫造铅水之时，从黄华起，故连名名言本耳。 又言雄黄黄华者，谓飞铅为霜雪铅者连，故言名本耳。 又言雄黄黄华者，谓飞故言雄也，所以言解也，所以言入者，铅太阳也，得阴则入，与黄华合，故言入耳。 所以言可覆雄仙药也，谓此二华混沌合为，包怀流珠，使精神不去。 故言可覆雄者，言阴抱阳包者覆也。 故言可覆雄者，铅也。 所以云为仙药者，言铅化为丹，不死药饵。 雄黄方好者一斤，以黄土釜二枚，以雄黄纳中，以一釜盖之，以白狗毛为泥，涂其会，令厚三分，亦可用赤石脂及牡砺若石垩灰为泥，涂其会，无令泄，阴乾七日，若数十日为佳。 炊以苇薪，临烧时视釜有细拆者，当更泥之。 临烧当作三头泥雀，先以一雀着釜上，雀燥下去，复一枚，燥复下去。 复上一枚，三雀尽燥，药成下釜玲之，问其火，无使大猛，亦勿令赢，药当上着釜，其色飘飘，或如霜雪白色，锺乳相连。 若烧之不熟，更与火如前法，亦当更泥釜如前。 成者，以取三岁白鸡羽左翼毛七枚，便扫下之，着铜器中。 若盘上讫已，取二百斤堵肠，熟洗之讫，以布拭肠令净洁讫，以药着中，紧结两头，着蒸箄中，以饭安上，以粟米一斛五斗若二斛，无者一石亦可，蒸之。 若肠烂，复以一肠加其上，一宿许，复加一肠着其上，蒸之三日三夜，用肠三枚，药成可丸。 丸如弹丸，服之三日，三虫尽死。 十日，伏尸下，夜视有光。 更臧其药，丸如麻子，常以平旦束向，再拜服之，天阴以日出所在服之，百日，冬衣单不寒，青腰玉女至，慎无以妻束西，常养玉女以求道。 百五十日，玉女去，更有玉女来，衣簪鼻上有玉，大如黍粟，是真玉女，慎无妻。 可即自谦寡昧腥躁臭处，圣人何肯，乃肯屈临之乎。 玉女曰：见子食神药，精光见乎天上，故令吾来，为子妻者。 慎无以妻，因谓之言寡昧闻玉英玉酒，五帝华池阳，未曾饮之，唯圣人为取之。 玉女即为取之，得而饮之，已俱徘徊六合之内，转上天关，与圣人相见，夜下天关，与真人共处清微之中，安用不死为名，辟沦陆沉，出无问，入无孔。 命曰：当斯之时，谨斋戒一纪。 所谓玉女者，天帝之女也。 常养者，白帝之女也。 青腰者，风伯之女。 欲还游以渡江海，恣意万世，为常一。 一方云：武都雄黄成，当如银。 若燥，以蜜和之。 道士常斋戒。
chunks.translated_text:
Lead is the Canopy, referring to divine water, hence called "lead’s yellow essence." When crafting lead water, it begins with the yellow essence, thus the name is derived from its origin. When realgar’s yellow essence is mentioned, it refers to flying lead becoming frost-like, hence the name is tied to its origin. When it speaks of realgar, it means "flying," thus the term *xiong* (male/realgar). The reason it speaks of "entering" is that lead is the Great Yang; when it meets yin, it enters and merges with the yellow essence. Thus, it is said to "enter."

The reason it speaks of "covering the elixir of male transcendents" is that these two essences merge in primordial chaos, enveloping the flowing pearl to preserve the spirit and prevent its departure. Thus, "covering" means yin embracing yang. Therefore, "covering the male" refers to lead. The reason it is called an "immortal elixir" is that lead transforms into cinnabar, the medicine of immortality.

For fine realgar, take one *jin*. Use two yellow clay crucibles, place the realgar inside one, and cover it with the other. Seal the seam with white dog’s hair mixed into mud, applying a layer three *fen* thick. Alternatively, use red halloysite, oyster shell powder, or limestone ash as sealant, ensuring no leaks. Let it dry in the shade for seven days, or even several tens of days for better results. Heat it with reed firewood. Before burning, inspect the crucible for fine cracks and reseal them. Before heating, fashion three mud sparrows. Place one on the crucible; when it dries, remove it and replace it with another. After the third sparrow dries, the medicine is ready. Remove the crucible and let it cool. Regulate the fire—neither too fierce nor too weak—so the medicine rises to the crucible’s lid, appearing ethereal, like frost or snow, with stalactite-like formations. If the medicine is not fully refined, repeat the firing as before, resealing the crucible as needed.

Once refined, take seven feathers from the left wing of a three-year-old white rooster and sweep the medicine into a bronze vessel or tray. Then, take two hundred *jin* of pig intestines, wash them thoroughly, and wipe them clean with cloth. Place the medicine inside, tie the ends tightly, and set it in a steamer. Place cooked rice on top, along with one *hu* and five *dou* of millet—or two *hu* if unavailable, or even one *shi*. Steam it. If the intestines rupture, add another layer on top. After one night, add another intestine, steaming for three days and three nights, using three intestines in total. The medicine will then be ready for shaping into pills.

Form the pills into the size of a crossbow pellet. After three days of ingestion, the Three Worms will die. After ten days, the corpse will descend, and at night, a glow will be visible. Refine the medicine further into sesame-sized pills. At dawn, face east, bow twice, and ingest them. On cloudy days, take them toward the sunrise. After a hundred days, even in winter, a single layer of clothing will suffice, and the Jade Maiden of the Azure Waist will arrive. Beware of taking a wife; instead, nurture the Jade Maiden to seek the Dao.

After a hundred and fifty days, the Jade Maiden will depart, and another will come, adorned with a jade hairpin on her nose, as large as a millet grain—this is the true Jade Maiden. Beware of marriage. One must remain humble, avoiding foul, rank, or impure places. How could a sage deign to descend to such?

The Jade Maiden said: "I saw you consume the divine medicine, and your radiant essence appeared in the heavens. Thus, I have come to be your wife." Beware of marriage. She then spoke of the solitary and ignorant, of jade blossoms and jade wine, of the Five Emperors’ Flowery Pond and the Yang of the Celestial Springs—things never tasted, only obtained by sages. The Jade Maiden then retrieved them, and after drinking, you will roam the Six Directions together, ascend the Celestial Pass, and meet the sages. At night, you will descend the Celestial Pass to dwell with the True Person in the Pure Subtlety. Why seek the name of immortality? You will transcend the mortal realm, entering and exiting without obstruction.

At this time, observe a twelve-year period of strict purification. The Jade Maiden is the daughter of the Heavenly Emperor. The one you nurture is the daughter of the White Emperor. The Azure-Waisted one is the daughter of the Wind Earl. If you wish to roam freely, crossing rivers and seas at will for ten thousand generations, remain ever constant.

Another method states: When Wu Du realgar is refined, it should resemble silver. If it dries, mix it with honey. Daoists must always observe purification rites.

**Methods of the True Person’s Divine Water (attached to various methods)**

The True Person’s method for making Divine Water: Take one *dou* of fine lacquer and place eighteen large, overnight-soaked crabs into it. After three days, they will dissolve into water, and the medicine will be complete, called Divine Water.

This Divine Water enables one to enter and exit without obstruction and command a hundred ghosts.

The method of ingestion: Mix one cup of clear wine with half a *ge* of Divine Water and drink it. In a secluded, tranquil place, after one day, the three worms in the abdomen will all be expelled. Then, partake of fine foods for fifteen days before drinking another small cup of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine. After two days, a three-foot-tall person will appear before you. Say, "Excellent! But do not speak with them at length, or the matter will not succeed." Then, partake of fine foods for another fifteen days before drinking one and a half cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine. After three days, even a team of four horses will be unable to catch you. After another fifteen days, drink two cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine, and your aspirations will soar, your sight and hearing sharpen. After another fifteen days, drink two and a half cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine, and white hair will turn black again, fallen teeth regrow. After another fifteen days, drink three cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine, and the elderly will become youths; on *jiǎzǐ* and *jiǎxū* days, spirits will arrive. After another fifteen days, drink three and a half cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine. After another fifteen days, drink four cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine; on *jiǎshēn* and *jiǎwǔ* days, spirits will arrive, the *Sea Chart* will appear, and you will enter and exit without obstruction. After another fifteen days, drink five cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine; on *jiǎchén* and *jiǎyín* days, spirits will arrive, and the *Sun and Moon Chart* will appear. After another fifteen days, drink six cups of Divine Water with one cup of clear wine, and you will neither sleep nor lie down. The *Chart of Heaven and Earth* will arrive, the Five Flowers will all come, you will cast no shadow, your calls will draw no echo, and you will be formless and indistinct, rising and sinking with heaven and earth. This is a secret—do not transmit it recklessly.

To compound the medicine, use the Immortal’s *Fèng Gāng* method. On the first day of the first month, take one *dou* of water and place all living flowers and plants into it. On the second day of the second month, take one *dou* of water and place all living flowers and plants into it. On the third day of the third month, take one *dou* of water and place all living flowers and plants into it. On the fourth day of the fourth month, take one *dou* of water and place all living flowers and plants into it. On the fifth day of the fifth month, take one *dou* of water and place all living flowers and plants into it. Seal and coat the containers, and each month, after collecting the water and flowers, reseal them to prevent leakage, storing them in a cold, dark place. From the sixth to the eighth month, whenever there are flowering plants, place them into the water without adding more water, mixing them into the existing infusion. On the ninth day of the ninth month, take another *dou* of water and place all living flowers and plants into it, then transfer it to a white jar, seal it tightly to prevent leakage, and store it in a cold place. Bury it indoors, three *chi* deep into the earth, and after a hundred days, all will dissolve. On a *wáng* day, simmer it over a gentle fire with a bundle of reeds, using bamboo for fuel, until it can be formed into pills. This medicine can revive the dead, transform forms, and alter bodies, allowing one to become a flying immortal. If a person has died and their breath is gone, place this medicine into their mouth, and they will revive.

If, after the prescribed days, the various ingredients have not dissolved, remove the dregs and mix them with *fú líng* and jujube paste, then take three pills the size of large soybeans at once, one dose per day, without missing a day.

Immortal Lǚ Gōng, styled Wénjìng, received the *Reviving the Dead* formula. It is said that Gōng left home for over two hundred years, and all his descendants had died. Upon his return, he exhumed the dead and applied the medicine to them, and they all revived with flesh and became human again, speaking clearly without error—over a hundred dead were brought back to life.

The formula: On the first day of the first month, take five *jīn* of bamboo roots. On the second day of the second month, take five *jīn* of pine roots. On the third day of the third month, take five *jīn* of parasol roots. On the fourth day of the fourth month, take five *jīn* of *rěn dōng* roots. This medicine revives flesh on white bones. Daoists who ingest it will prolong their years, prevent their hair from turning white, their teeth from falling out, and their faces from losing luster. Zhi (fungi/immortality herbs) come in many kinds: mushroom zhi, herbaceous zhi, woody zhi, and flesh zhi. They commonly grow on high mountains, beneath large trees, and beside spring waters. Mushroom zhi appear in five colors: red ones resemble cinnabar, black ones like fine lacquer, white ones like frost and snow, yellow ones like refined gold, green ones like the head feathers of a drake, purple ones like newly dyed purple silk, and crimson ones like peach blossoms. To determine whether it is true zhi, dry it in the shade for a hundred days—if its color remains unchanged, it is genuine.

When entering famous mountains to gather zhi and herbs, one must first purify through fasting. Do not enter the homes of the bereaved or those where a woman has recently given birth, and abstain from pungent and meaty foods. Wear white garments, carry a white chicken, and hold a peck of white salt; alternatively, lead a white dog, and you will surely encounter zhi. Zhi may have two, three, four, or even five layers, with the most potent having nine layers. All can be consumed to attain immortality, allowing one to fly, see through all things, and command ghosts and spirits.

The method for gathering zhi is as follows: In spring, during the first, second, and third months, do not enter the mountains on *yin-mao* (寅卯) or *jia-yi* (甲乙) days. In summer, during the fourth, fifth, and sixth months, avoid *si-wu* (巳午) or *bing-ding* (丙丁) days. In autumn, during the seventh, eighth, and ninth months, do not enter on *shen-you* (申酉) or *geng-xin* (庚辛) days. In winter, during the tenth, eleventh, and twelfth months, avoid *hai-zi* (亥子) or *ren-gui* (壬癸) days.

To gather green zhi, go at dawn on *jia-yi* days when the sun rises, approaching from the east. Cut it with a wooden knife and store it in nine feet of green silk. For red zhi, go at mid-morning or noon on *bing-ding* days, approaching from the south. Cut it with a fish knife and store it in eight feet of crimson silk. For yellow zhi, go at dusk on *wu-ji* days, approaching from the northwest. Cut it with a metal knife and store it in one foot of yellow silk. For black zhi, go at midnight on *ren-gui* days, approaching from the north. Cut it with a bone knife and store it in five feet of black silk. For white zhi, go at sunset on *geng-xin* days, approaching from the west. Cut it with a wooden knife and store it in six feet of white silk.

Flesh zhi include thousand-year-old bats, thousand-year-old spirit turtles, thousand-year-old swallows, and thousand-year-old swans. Consuming them grants immortality. A thousand-year-old bat is pure white and roosts upside down; eating it raw confers immortality. A thousand-year-old spirit turtle has horns on its head and a luminous shell with five-colored flames. Roast its shell, grind it into powder, and take a square-inch spoonful three times daily to become immortal. A thousand-year-old swallow nests facing north; eating it grants immortality. A thousand-year-old swan sings once every two hours, day and night, and is smaller than an ordinary swan. Roast its bones, grind them into powder, and take a square-inch spoonful three times daily to become immortal.

*The Divine Immortal Recipes of Huainan* states: Things take form according to their kind—stalactites differ from pine mistletoe, which differs from mulberry mistletoe. This is the natural Dao of growth. Thus, when consumed, they harmonize with the six pitch-pipes and correspond to the seven stars.

Rehmannia root is the essence of the indistinct and imperceptible. Mulberry mistletoe is the essence of yang. Chrysanthemum blossoms are the essence of yin. Poria is the essence of wood. Plantago seeds are the essence of thunder and lightning. Kochia seeds are the essence of the constellations. Bamboo seeds are the essence of celestial blossoms and the Great One. These seven substances correspond to the seven stars of the Northern Dipper, encompassing the sun, moon, and five phases. When consumed in measured proportions, after nine days of purification, on the kingly days of the four seasons, take a pinch with three fingers of well-flower water, facing the sun. Drink once on yang days and twice on yin days. After forty-nine days, one will suddenly vanish.

In the first year of the Tianfeng era, Chen Yongbo of Nanyang had his nephew consume this medicine. After twenty-eight days, he suddenly disappeared without a trace.
